sect2.title: Location-Speakers
sect2.para: Old Babylonian is a variety of the Semitic Akkadian language-group, a closely related set of geographically and chronologically differentiated language varieties attested in written (cuneiform) sources from Mesopotamia (roughly, present-day Iraq) from the middle of the third millennium to the last centuries B.C.E. Old Babylonian as documented here is the standard variety of the language used in Southern Mesopotamia, centered around the political capitol Baylon during the first half of the second millennium B.C.E.

note.para: There is a huge scholarly literature on Old Babylonian. The source followed here is the excellent pedagogical grammar:

sect1.title: akkadian-OB Paradigm Lexemes
sect1.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms
lemma gloss properties
akuš go ablautClass=uClass, rootClass=aCC
alik go ablautClass=a-iClass, rootClass=aCC
amur see ablautClass=a-uClass, rootClass=aCC
arik be long ablautClass=iClass, rootClass=aCC
bni build rootClass=CCi
bnʾ build rootClass=CCw
dʾk kill rootClass=CūC
epuš do ablautClass=e-uClass, rootClass=eCC
erub enter ablautClass=uClass, rootClass=eCC
ezib leave ablautClass=iClass, rootClass=eCC
kūn be rootClass=CūC
kʾn be(come) firm rootClass=CūC
lqe take rootClass=CCe
lqʾ take rootClass=CCw
mal be full rootClass=CCa
mlʾ be(come) full of rootClass=CCw
mnʾ count rootClass=CCw
mʾt die rootClass=CūC
nkis cut off ablautClass=iClass, rootClass=nCC
nqur tear down ablautClass=a-uClass, rootClass=CCC
nsuk throw ablautClass=uClass, rootClass=nCC
nēr kill rootClass=CēC
nʾl lie down rootClass=CūC
nʾr slay rootClass=CūC
prs separate rootClass=CCC
prus divide ablautClass=a-uClass, rootClass=CCC
qīš give CīC=rootClass
qʾš give rootClass=CūC
wbl bear rootClass=wCC
wld beget rootClass=wCC
wrd descend rootClass=wCC
wrid go down ablautClass=a-iClass, rootClass=wCC
wšr release lemma=wšr, gloss=release, setfree=pdgmLexLabel, attributes={
šriq steal ablautClass=iClass, rootClass=CCC
šāl ask CāC=rootClass
šʾl ask rootClass=CūC
šʾm buy rootClass=CūC
ḫdu be glad rootClass=CCu
ṣbat seize ablautClass=aClass, rootClass=CCC

sect1.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
sect1.para: OB Akkadian paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para:
OB Akkadian, in common with the rest of Semitic has a more extensive (and more archaic) set of gender distinctions than is found in Cushitic outside of Beja:
number person gender
sg p1 "⊤"
sg p2 "m"
sg p2 "f"
sg p3 m
sg p3 m
sg p3 f
pl p1 "⊤"
pl p2 "m"
pl p2 "f"
pl p3 "m"
pl p3 "f"
I.e., where gender is distinguished not only in the third-person singular, but also in the third-person plural, and in the second-person singular and plural.

Ventive: stem which can be formed from all theme-stems by suffixation of -am (where -m- assimilates to following consonant)and which basically indicates orientation toward speaker (as in {alākum} 'to go' {alākum}+-am 'to come'), but with many other variant semantic effects.

inflectionClass: as in all languages, phonological and grammaticization processes conspire to create more or less marked morphophonemic differences in the verbal inflections of different sets of verbs.
perfect: a tense specific to Akkadian, formed by -t- infixation.

precative: For first and third person (thus suppletive with the imperative; prefix l(i)- for third person (no gender distinction in the singular!), l(u)- for first person singular, i- for first person plural. Corresponds to the general Semitic jussive.

sect1.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
sect1.para:
The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first simply lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The second listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,⊤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].
